target_text: "It is difficult to define and measure. That’s for sure. I think before agile, there was a great focus on product level quality. Mainly free of defects and meets customer’s needs. I saw in agile a shift toward code quality and a design that responds to change. There is also a continuous improvement of the process effort."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

codebook.justification: The speaker asserts [It is difficult to define and measure.], foregrounding construct validity tensions and subjective operationalization choices.
They describe pre-agile emphasis on [product level quality], privileging defect metrics and perceived fit to [customer’s needs].
Agile is framed as [a shift toward code quality], indicating normative evaluation of internal maintainability over external deliverables.
They value [continuous improvement of the process], signaling a kaizen-style process lens that is interpretive, not strictly measurable.
